clinical_study.brief_title: Non-Invasive Management of Chronic Venous Insufficiency
clinical_study.official_title: Non-Invasive Management of Chronic Venous Insufficiency

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is:
-item one to use two new non-invasive technologies to evaluate scarring and swelling associated with chronic venous insufficiency.
The study hypothesis:
- item one non-invasive technologies can provide a tool for assessing risk of ulcer development based on the tissue edema and alteration.

primary_outcome.measure: To provide device development to assess tissue changes associated with chronic venous insufficiency

secondary_outcome.measure: To compare device development to existing clinical measurement

arm_group.description: Varicose veins, varicose veins with leg swelling, venous stasis skin color changes, no open ulcers
Subjects with no venous disease CEAP (clinical etiology antomy pathophysiology)Class 0

study_pop.textblock: CVI subjects will be recruited from University of Utah vascular surgery service.Control group will be recruited from the community.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- participants with CVI with CEAP class 4 or higher
- participants with no CVI class 0
Exclusion Criteria:
- open ulcers or lower extremity amputation
- diabetics with HbA1C greater than 7.0
- arterial occlusive disease
- BMI greater than 35
- any connective tissue disorder (lipodermatosclerosis and fibrosis)
- participants with metallic prosthesis or implants
- participants with renal impairment
- pregnancy
- inability or refusal to wear compression stockings prescribed by physician (CVI patients only)
